instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1534: What is A1534? A1534 is a model number for a 12 inch size Macbook  from years 2015, 2016 with EMC 2746, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00045, 820-00244..
definitions.820-00244: What is 820-00244? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PP5V_S4: What is PP5V_S4? PP5V_S4 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS: What is PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS? This power rail is PPBUS_G3H after going through a current sense resistor that sits between PPBUS_G3H & the input of PPBUS_G3H to circuitry that provides power for the CPU..
definitions.PPVIN_G3H_P3V3G3H: What is PPVIN_G3H_P3V3G3H? This is the input from the USB-C charger or the battery that is the input voltage for the chip responsible for creating PP3V3_G3H. It can be missing when capacitors on this line are shorted to ground, or when the diode in front of it leading to the chip that creates PP3V3_G3H is blown. .
definitions.PP3V3R3V0_AON: What is PP3V3R3V0_AON? PP3V3R3V0_AON is the first power rail you need to get a USB-C charger to go from 5v to 20v on an A1534 Macbook with an 820-00045 board..
definitions.PP5V_G3H: What is PP5V_G3H? PP5V_G3H is a 5v rail present when the machine is in a G3H mechanical off state.
definitions.PP1V8_SUS: What is PP1V8_SUS? PP1V8_SUS is a 1.8v power rail active in a suspend state..
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.SMC_ONOFF: What is SMC_ONOFF? SMC_ONOFF is a signal that tells the machine that the power button has been pressed so it knows to turn on, or turn off. .
definitions.PM_SLP_S3_L: What is PM_SLP_S3_L? PM_SLP_S3_L puts the machine to sleep in an S3 state when it is asserted, the _L means it is asserted when it is low voltage. When this signal is 3.3v the machine will be asked to turn on S0 power rails and begin the bootup process.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Not turning on
threads.message:
Hi, this is my first post and I am a total noob so bear with me. :)

History: Was working and someone removed the LVDS cable before pushing the battery disconnect button and after that it was dead. (This is atleast how the story goes :)
No signs of liquid damage.

Charger voltage 15v and it is not taking any current. (Don?t know if the battery is full).
Don?t know what should I measure for you, so just tell me what values you want and I will gladly get them.

Here are some measurements from the board:

<TRANSISTOR>Q3100</TRANSISTOR> Pin-8 = 14.7V
<SIGNAL>PPVIN_G3H_P3V3G3H</SIGNAL> = 14.7V
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 8.7V

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS</SIGNAL> = 8.7V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_G3H</SIGNAL> = 5V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> = 5V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL> = 0 V

<SIGNAL>PP3V3R3V0_AON</SIGNAL> = 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> =  3.3V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> = 0V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_SUS</SIGNAL>= 0V  (pulsing?)
<SIGNAL>P1V8SUS_PGOOD</SIGNAL>= 0V

Any help or suggestions would be much appreciated. Thanks in advance!

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Not turning on
threads.message:
LCD connector has NO voltage when board is off.
But working on that machine with battery enabled can result in really dead board.
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> is present and also <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is high.

Disconnect battery and check if board tries to start when connect charger.
Also try disconecting LCD screen.

"<SIGNAL>PP1V8_SUS</SIGNAL>= 0V (pulsing?)"
If really pulses, all S4/3 voltages and signals should pulse too; check that.
Start checking if you get at least one pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>.
Better to see that when trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ON_OFF_L</SIGNAL> to ground; use <RESISTOR>R5225</RESISTOR>/26 pads.

BTW, there is no LVDS cable; panel is eDP type.
However, we understood what LVDS cable means in your post.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Not turning on
threads.message:
Thanks for the quick response.

Aah, ok. Nice to know, that there is no voltage on the display connector. And the panel type.

All measurements are done with just the board and PSU. I took the board out before doing anything.

I might have wrong word for pulsing, sorry. My multimeter has a line that makes pulses and that what I have tried to describe. Other S3/4 voltages are not "pulsing" when I measured them.

<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> rises to 0.06V when <SIGNAL>SMC_ON_OFF_L</SIGNAL>  is shorted to ground.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Not turning on
threads.message: Do NOT use a PSU for these USBC is not the same as magsafe....use a known good OEM 87 watt brick and cable and see what happens.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Not turning on
threads.message:
[QUOTE="JohnB8812, post: 47609"]Do NOT use a PSU for these USBC is not the same as magsafe....use a known good OEM 87 watt brick and cable and see what happens.[/QUOTE]

Yeah, of course not. Sorry for the confusion. I am using the 29W Apple original USB-C power supply.

I had another customers 87W for a while and otherwise same results, but got 20V on <TRANSISTOR>Q3100</TRANSISTOR> Pin-8.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Not turning on
threads.message:
Do not short <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> to ground.
You must simulate power button, only make temporary contact.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Not turning on
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 47617"]Do not short <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> to ground.
You must simulate power button, only make temporary contact.[/QUOTE]

Yes, I did that and the <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> rises to 0.06V the moment it is shorted (as simulated the power button would be pressed down) and goes to 0V after releasing the "button".

I consider myself a total newbie, but not that much that I would leave it shorted. I used tweezers. But I totally understand that it is good to make these clear. Thanks for that and sorry if my English is not that precise. Not my native language.

What does the rise in the <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> mean or could you please tell what should I check next?
This board should start up when the power (USB) is connected or do I remember wrong from Louis videos?

I saw voltage fluctuation on <SIGNAL>CPUCORE_PHASE1</SIGNAL> from 0.2-1.2V but went back to 0V soon. This happened when I just measured after leaving it on the table with the charger connected, before shorting the <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF</SIGNAL>.

Any tips or suggestion would be great as the customer is coming to pick up the device tomorrow, repaired or not. Don?t get me wrong, I really appreciate all the help and I don?t want to sound ungrateful.

Thanks!

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Not turning on
threads.message:
Board should start automatically, like all MacBook iCore platforms.

"I saw voltage fluctuation on <SIGNAL>CPUCORE_PHASE1</SIGNAL> from 0.2-1.2V"
Then all secondary voltages should pulse too; less iGPU (GT) probably.
Do you note pulsing every 5s, or only 1-2 times when connect charger?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Not turning on
threads.message:
Thanks for the reply.

I will check the pulsing as soon as I am back at the shop.
Just to be clear, do you mean the S4/S3 lines with secondary voltages or what should I check? Also do you mean fluctuating voltage with pulsing?

Sorry, just want to be clear as I am still very new with these.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Not turning on
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> enables S3 voltages.
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> enables S0 voltages.
CPU VCORE voltage is S0 type; if that pulses, all other should too.
iGPU voltage maybe not...
An o-scope can help you to check if pulses reach nominal voltage on the coils.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Not turning on
threads.message:
Thanks for that. Nice to know about the enables.
Should there be voltage on those or are they just datalines that would need an o-scope to see something?

Well I don?t detect "pulsing" on <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> and S3 lines at any point, but I don?t have a o-scope and my multimeter testing is probably wrong to say pulsing in the first place.

Never could see the voltage again in <SIGNAL>CPUCORE_PHASE1</SIGNAL>.

Is there anything else that I could measure for you?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Not turning on
threads.message:
Customer picked up the device. You can close the thread.

Thanks for 2informaticos for all your help!
PS. If you want to throw your wild guess what have might been the issue it would be nice so I can learn more from this.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Not turning on
threads.message:
There are several signals need to check.
We usually ask for few of them and see which one else to verify.
Is better to assist directly on the board.
